comments.text:
It is very tricky to print.
1) take a look at the picture of my make, notice I have used meshmixer to build supports and a base at a odd angle. it will not print flat
2) I use a Replicator 2 with 230 C 0.2mm build, 90mm/sec
3) it can't be downsized much as it will fail to have enough material / to thin of walls unless you have a ultra-fine printer
4) Preview the slice... any voids?... try again.

title: OpenPilot GPS v9 holder with mounts for Tubular Crossfire 2

description.text: This is a remix of OpenPilot GPS v9 holder (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:637547) but with added legs to support the holder above your choice of Autopilot (i'm using a revo in the attached images). The dimensions of these legs are designed to fit on the Tubular Crossfire 2 QuadCopter (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:261298). I wanted the extra legs (rather than just a single pole) to provide stability as I wanted to print in Nylon. I wanted to use Nylon as it would give me some flex in situations where my landings were not all that perfect (aka crash).
As I wanted strength and flex I printed these in Nylon with 100% fill.

The fixing device LCD for Rostock.
Description here: http://eca3d.blogspot.ru/2015/05/rostock-9-lcd.html

Floating Puck This Thing is a simple, hollow, cylindrical puck which fits inside my [Water Level Sensor Housing]() to provide the Sharp Infrared Distance Sensor with a solid, matte black surface to reflect off of. It has an outer diameter of 44mm, giving it 2mm of clearance on all sides within the 48mm (inner diameter) Water Level Sensor Housing. Preparation
ABS plastic (and possibly PLA plastic, as well) tends to degrade and "leach" into water, so it is advisable to thoroughly coat the entire part in some sort of sealant. I used Clear Shellac Spray since I had it lying around the house anyways, and it has the benefit of being non-toxic and natural Lac resin-based (a type of insect resin), which is used to coat food products, and should avoid issues of contamination in a sensitive environment (like an aquarium or food-contact setting) when used in room temperature or lower water-based liquids. An acrylic coating may be preferable in situations where chemical contamination of any kind is unacceptable.

Design
Like all of my parts, I used Autodesk Fusion 360 CAD software, UP slicer program, and an UP Mini printer.
In Fusion, I sketched a circle, extruded it upwards, then shelled it, added a top, and joined all components. Printing
For 3D printing settings, it doesn't matter which infill settings you use, other than 90-100%, which might prevent the puck from floating. hollow shell settings will work, as will (up to) 90% infill. Support structures are not needed, since there is no overhang in this Thing. A raft IS recommended to ensure a good base shape free from distortion.

This is a two-piece Thing: Top Tube and Bottom Tube. This Thing combines with my Sharp GP2Y0A21 IR Sensor Housing and IR Sensor Puck to form an infrared water level measurement sensor.

  • The two pieces fit together in a friction / pressure fit. The cylinder is perforated to provide visual indication of the puck, water level, and any obstructing debris.

  • The top three threads are 4mm ANSI M Metric threads at 17mm deep, and join the IR Sensor Housing to the tube structure.
    • If I were to re-mix this part, I would remove the side perforations, and replace them with a vertical "window", either completely plastic-free, or with a transparent material. This would eliminate ripples in the body of water from affecting the puck and therefore the sensor reading, by extending the tube under the water's surface. I might add an "intermediate" tube section, so users can extend the housing, up to 80cm long (Sharp's listed max distance for the IR sensor) I will coat the part in an inert, non-toxic, Lac-based spray enamel to prevent the degradation of the ABS plastic in water.

Design
Like all of my parts, I used Autodesk Fusion 360 CAD software, UP slicer program, and an UP Mini printer.

  • In Fusion 360, I first sketched a cylinder of 54mm diameter. Then, I sketched a 48mm cylinder inside the first, and Extrude > Cut to leave a 6mm shell. A circle was cut from the cylinder, and I created a circular pattern to repeat the perforations. Extruding vertically also repeated the perforations, saving a considerable amount of time.

  • I imported the IR Sensor Casing and created the screw hole cylinders, then cut the two in half and exported them separately.

  • To emboss (deboss?) the text onto the cylinder, I created a text sketch in a midplane of the cylinder, then created a shell around the outside of the cylinder. Using the Extrude tool, I extruded the text sketch "To" the inside of the shell, which was spaced about 1mm wider than the housing OD. Next, I sketched a 48mm circle and cut the inside of the housing, to leave only the extruded text. Lastly, I joined all the bodies (which were separate for each letter) to help organize the project. A dedicated "Eboss" feature in Fusion would be nice, but until then this is the method Autodesk recommends.

  • Because of the height limitations of the UP Mini printer (4.75" vertical), I chose to split the part into two. This also allows an intermediate extension part to be added between the top and bottom to extend the sensor distance.

  • The "Max Water Level" text indicates the minimum distance the puck need to be for the Sharp IR sensor to function properly, since the voltage varies with distance accordingly
    • Printing Printing of this Thing is somewhat tricky, because of it's "complex" shape, in terms of support structures.

  • I'd recommend printing the Top and Bottom side-by-side, vertically. This will prevent warping of the edges if you were to print them on their sides.

  • Enabling the support option in your slicing program is definitely recommended, to avoid warping of the perforations, joining middle section, and screw columns.

  • Minimum layer height is probably best in order to print the text and threads(I used 0.2mm), but the build time can reach 8-10 hours at even "moderate" settings; a .1mm layer height could potentially double your build time.
    • Preparation
    ABS plastic (and possibly PLA plastic, as well) tends to degrade and "leach" into water, so it is advisable to thoroughly coat the entire part in some sort of sealant. I used Clear Shellac Spray since I had it lying around the house anyways, and it has the benefit of being non-toxic and natural Lac resin-based (a type of insect resin), which is used to coat food products, and should avoid issues of contamination in a sensitive environment (like an aquarium or food-contact setting) when used in room temperature or lower water-based liquids. An acrylic coating may be preferable in situations where chemical contamination of any kind is unacceptable.

title: Robo3D warped bed fix (high center/low sides)

description.text:
THIS FIX IS NOT FOR EVERYONE.
If your bed is flat from front to back but you notice that extruder tip gets closer to the bed as it passes center of the bed and drops down toward the opposite end, then this fix is for you. Used old threaded rod left from Z axis.
Nuts and adjusting bolt are specified in the picture. When tension is applied by the screw, screw pushes against the bed (there is a pushpin between the bed to keep it from scratching) it pushes center of the bed down or pulling the sides up (not sure which) flattening it for me.
I only needed to put one of those at the front. You may have to use two. Try one out on both ends to see if one fixes the problem all the way.
Good luck . I guess here is no such thing as FLAT in robo3d printers. This was my 3rd bed. 1st was broken, second was warped beyond acceptable and this one is no where perfect without this device.

comments.text: Great idea. One other thing to try is rotating the X axis rods. I was having the same problem and found the rods had a slight bend. By rotating them I was able to get the head tracking the bed. You want the bow in the rods to be rotated up a little and either both in or out. That way the bow slightly up compensates for the weight of the print head. The in or out will affect the tracking in the Yaxis. If they are both in or out one offsets the other and the head tracks flat in the Y axis.

comments.text: You must have watched my video https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zqbmxYvDPmI ?
comments.author: n23d

comments.text: were you having adhesion problems? How would one determine if this fix would be of use to them? I am curious to check mine to see if it is 100% flat

If bed is perfect on all 4 corners (Front left and right as well as back left and right) but getting closer to nozzle in the center (from left to right, not from back to front) then this fix is for you.

title: SSR - solid state relay for AC powered heatbed - selfmade (5€)

description.text:
Solid state relay (SSR) for AC powered heatbed. If you have an high power AC heatbed you need a SSR to use it with you RAMPS or similar. Primary power: 12 VDC or 24 VDC
Secondary power: 230 VAC up to 2A (8A with additional cooling) Please tell me if you need other attachment brackets. Thanks to "Hardwarekiller" from RepRapForum for the idea with that Sharp part. One last sentence:
If you build/use this relay you are dealing with deadly voltage. Be careful!

All you need is: 1 Set printed parts
1 Solid State Relais, Sharp S202 S02 (3,10 €)
1 Resistor 5,6k Ohm (0,30 €)
1 Clamp (4 pole) (0,40 €)
1 Fuse 2 - 3,5 A (0,08 €)
1 Fusebox (1,10 €)
1 PCB 29 x 29 mm
3 Nuts DIN 934 M3
3 Bolts DIN 912 M3x20 or similar I bought my parts at: reichelt.de
Here are the needed part numbers:
S202 S02
MPR 5,60K
AKL 101-04
TRÄGE 3,15A
PL FPG1-40
UP 730 EP

description.text:
The Earplug Cable Tidy lets you securely wind up the cable and protects mobile device Earplugs. Once you've used it a few times it's quick and easy to keep your Earplugs safe and the cable wound away tidily. Quick and easy to use:

  • Thread the end plug through one of the holes in the Earplug Cable Tidy (You will need to work out which hole best suits the length of your Earplug Cable to retain the cable securely),

  • Pull the cable all the way through until the Earplugs are safely positioned (protected) inside the centre area of the Earplug Tidy

  • Firmly wind the cable around the outside of the Earplug Cable Tidy
    • 4.Push the end plug through the hole in the Earplug Tidy that provide just enough length to push it across the top of the Earplugs (securing them so they can't come out) and fully into the end plug securing hole. Note: Different sets of Earplugs have different length cables. Determine which hole suits your cable best to retain the Earplugs securely in the central area and fully insert the end plug into the securing hole. You will probably need to push the wound up cable down a fraction to push the end plug back into the central area. If you like this check out more of my Thingiverse listings!
On a Replicator 2 and 5th Generation Replicator the Earplug Cable Tidy prints well at Std./0.20mm resolution with 3 shells and 35% infill. Use Raft but no support required.

UPDATE 23-APR-2016 (see openscad file V.24):
  • Bugfix: Boom flight position stoppers adapt to QUAD_W > 50°
  • Feature: Stoppers with cylindrical filled frame geometry (StopperFill)
    • UPDATE 04-MAR-2016 (see openscad file V.23):
  • Bugfix: boom slots are symmetric now, even with Quad_W > 45°
  • Additional "top cover" added for customizer selection ("cov") e.g. for GPS
  • Some parameters fine tuneable
    • UPDATE 28-FEB-2016 (see openscad file):
    V.22 adapted to Customizer:
  • Most components selectable via customizer
  • Main dimensions and features are widely customizable
  • Boom hinge optimized for better motor cable packaging
  • Top frame optionally w/o flight controller fixing domes
  • Legs with variable extended height for "low hanging" gimbals
  • Many more small optimizations due to customizer calculations
    • UPDATE 25-07-2015 (see openscad file):
    V.20 with additional motor type:
  • Boom with holder for motor DYS BX1306 (HK #66402) added
    (motor with standard fixation concept by 4 screws), very robust!
    see openscad file (or fnq220_boom-bx1306_v19.stl)
  • Remark: This boom is printed with the propeller side up
    (the HK2811 boom must be printed upside down)
  • Adapter plate for FC Flip32-mini added (fits onto 31x31 footprint)
  • Remaining parts are unchanged (can be used from V.18)
  • My "FNQ #2" is coming (black magic PLA) with the DYS motors
    --> see gallery photo...
    .
    • UPDATE 19-07-2015 (see openscad file):
    V.18 with significant improvements over V.15:
  • Motor holder strengthened (robust motor fixation even with PLA)
  • Legs strengthened (can be printed rotated sideways)
  • Lower case strengthened (wider ESC holders)
  • Default size increased to 90x70mm
  • Plate for FC with 30.5 x 30.5mm footprint (Naze32, CC3D, Flip32)
  • Antenna holder for Jeti RSAT (optional)
  • LED holder for 2 x Neopixel 5x5mm (optional)
    • Maiden flight went perfect with this version (using Lipo 2s 800mAh, HK 2811-2000 motors, AfroFlight rev5, Jeti RSAT1).

A small quadrocopter with 220mm motor distance for direct drive motors. All booms are foldable, so it fits in a small bag to carry everywhere... 10g brushless HK 2811-2000 motors plug into the motor holder w/o additional fixing bracket, their cables are protected inside the booms. Between lower and upper frame there is space for 4 x Plush 6A ESCs and a flight controller with 30.5x30.5mm or 45x45mm footprint sits on top.  
All components are designed to be printed in PLA w/o additional support structures. The hollow booms are weight optimized and fixed with M3 screws to the frame, so they can be printed even with tiny 3D printers.  
The complete quad is designed with parametric main dimensions, so it's easy to be "extended" from 86mm frame length up to 160mm, if additional space for FPV, gimbals etc. is required.  
The frame parts have simple design, only with fixation for ESC, battery and FC. Further bling-bling may be added later. Feel free to play with the design!

The design started with the idea to create a parametric motor mount for smaller brushless outrunner motors for my little quadrocopters.  
Adding the "fold" feature and a frame all around it was a lot of fun with OpenSCAD, all components are written with parametric dimensions.  
Everything prints w/o heat bed and w/o additional support structures in PLA on my DIY deltaprinter.   
Break away the inner tube in the motor holder, it is only a support structure to print the improved inner motor flange.  
Use a 2mm drill for the small thread holes at the motor flange (in PLA drill slowly by hand), then drill a M2.5 thread there. You also can try to set the M2.5 screws which come with the 2811-2000 motors directly if you drill the holes diameter a little bigger before.  
The 4x Plush 6A ESC can be placed inside the lower shell, each one in its own chamber, so no shrink tube is required. Use 1 power cable to connect them all in a daisychain. Its a good idea to place the big input elkos on top of the ESC to get more space there.  
Check the motor temperature after test flight. The motors should not become too hot, otherwise the motor might become loose in the PLA boom holder. Some drops of CA glue inside the motor holder (before inserting the motors!) could stiffen the structure in this case.  
Have fun printing, building and flying your own!

title: Budget Rail - Low Cost, Rigid Rail System

description.text:
Made from low cost parts, this rail system given the accuracy and reliability of other expensive rail systems, with parts which are available in almost any location. Budgetrail is designed to use 40mm square aluminium extrusion. The rail runs true and has very little if any backlash - something I've experienced only while putting far more lateral force than my printer will ever exert. A 4mm adjustment screw allows for fine tuning the rail to get the best balance of smooth movement with minimal backlash. During the design of my 3D printer, I discovered regular rail systems were expensive. My printer is a 2m tall delta, and finding cheap, locally sourced T slot rails or makerslide extrusion in 2m lengths was going to be very costly. The other design consideration was fact that generally rail systems can flex - especially over a 2m length. This rail system remains rigid over 2m spans and performs incredibly reliably. To complete this rail, you will need the following (per rail)
1x 40mm square aluminium extrusion (Im using 1.5mm wall thickness) (Costs about $50AUD for a 6m length) It is important the corners of the Aluminium Square Tube are un damaged. I used square corner tube, but experimented with radiused corners which seem to work smoother, possibly from less surface friction.
3x 55mm M8 Bolts (I printed mine)
3x M8 Nuts (I printed mine)
6x 608ZZ Skateboard bearings (high quality ABEC 5?)
9x M8 washers (I printed mine)
All parts can only be printed with the large face down. I have also included the rod arm joint for those who wish to use this rail in their delta printer.
1x 10mm M3 Bolt and nut
1x 40mm (approx) M3 Bot and Nut (I used threaded rod with a nut at each end).
1x M4 15mm Screw
1x 12mm x 3mm Round magnet, or M3 socket bolt for endstop. (Version photographed does not have the bed for these, however the stl files have been updated to include both hole for m3 bolt and magnet mounting position. You choose which you prefer. Any questions, please let me know.

Construction.
First, if using this for a Delta printer such as my soon to be released "Elevator", you will need to attach the arm-joint to the "Left Bracket" using suitable length bolts. Next, Into the Left Bracket, Insert M8 55mm bolt with bearings and washers in the following order, through to the opposing hole in the right bracket : Washer, bearing, washer, bearing, washer. Basically this should create a small gap between the two bearings and a small gap either side to prevent the bearing from contacting the brackets (carriers). Fix the M8 nut loosely over the end of the bolt - you will tighten this later Repeat the above 2 steps for the remaining 2 bolts. Slide the carrier over your 40mm rail and insert your M4 tensioning screw into the tensioning hole (although holes for tensioning bolts are on both sides of the carrier bracket, it is only necessary to use one of them. (see picture) Tighten the tensioning screw enough to get a nice smooth slide with little resistance. Too much and you'll chew your rails to bits, too little and backlash will be introduced. Notes: After nearly 2 weeks printing 24/7, I can see very small amounts of grooving (expected) in my aluminium rail from the harder metal of the bearings, wearing into the rail. This is very easily modified every so often by adjusting the tensioning screw. If in a few years time, the rail needs replacing - so be it. $50 for 6m length of Aluminium square tube is a small price to pay.

description.text:
I was showing off some of my designs at a recent Makerbot user group meeting, and I wished I had tags for them with QR codes and some other relevant data. This bookmarklet will generate such tags.
This is a smaller version, with the QR code on one side and the human-readable information on the other.
Note: I initially set the license to CC-BY for the example picture because the CC licenses look a little nicer on the tags, but I've changed the license to PD, so feel free to use it however you want.
Update: Some errors were reported with the DOM walking, so I rewrote those portions to use Regex instead. This should improve compatibility.

Navigate to the page for the Thing you want to tag, then run the script. It will grab the relevant data and format it for tag printing. I haven't done extensive testing, but it should work in all standards-compliant browsers (old versions of IE might have a problem). Print the tag, cut it out and fold it over. Fold the end over into a triangle (for strength), then punch a hole and attach with string to the printed thing. Note: Thingiverse won't let me post a javascript link (this would be a security issue), and the text gets a little mangled if I post it here. To get the script, download the .js file, copy the contents and paste it into your address bar or create a bookmark using the full script as the URL. Update: for those still having trouble, you can get bookmarkable links for Thingitag and Thingitag Jr. at http://whosawhatsis.com/paraphernalia/thingitag.html Update: I fixed these for the new Thingiverse design AGAIN, and I'm getting sick of it. It works, but I've only tested it in Chrome. If your browser of choice doesn't work, use Chrome instead.

This is a model of a table top foam cutter, printed in 4 parts. The base is 100x100x30mm and the available height of cutting wire is 90mm. A NiChrome wire or guitar string and a DC power supply is required. I have found that the best electrical parameters are 1-1.5V and 1.2-2A depending on the temperature required. It is also possible to cut thin plastic parts such as PLA or HIPS sheet, as well as paper. The back plate attaches with four 4mm self-tapping screws and a 7mm diameter compression spring is used to ensure the wire stays taught. I suggest a spring rate of 2N/mm or greater. A 6mm diameter 25mm long bar fits in the slot on the underside for wrapping the wire around. Channels have been made around the outside edge of the arm and under the base for routing power cables. Corner rounds and fillets have been applied to prevent issues with slight print overrun on interference fit components. Please take a moment to look over the finer features of the model to ensure they will print well with your machine. STEP files provided for editing and other formats may be available on request. *** If you have found this model useful, please support me by donating $0.99 by downloading from this link: http://3dsha.re/product/table-top-foam-cutter/ Thanks! ***

All parts can be printed without supports apart from the arm. For this I used the 'support everywhere' option in Cura.   
Base is best printed with the top face against the build plate.  
Printed at 50mm/s and 20% infill, the base takes approximately 3 hrs 30 mins. The remaining parts take 1 hr total at 100% infill.  
The STL files provided use dimension tolerances that work well with my printer, a DreamMaker Overlord (delta style). STEP files have been provided for you to tweak as required.   
I would suggest printing the base first and then tweaking the other part dimensions to fit.  
As a rule of thumb: Internal diameters have been increased by 0.5mm.

author: hinge

description.text:
Rustedrobot reports that there are alignment problems with the gears from the clockwork library. Some of that can be fixed by making the gears thicker, and tightening the tolerances between the gears and the shafts they sit on... but he points out that herringbone gears might really help.
I implemented herringbone gears in the clockwork library, made sure they meshed, and while I was at it, beefed up the pinions and introduced a little (parametric) space between the two gears of a wheel... because with herringbone gears, the gears MUST line up.

To use the herringbone option, call the pinion modules normally (pinionWheel, pinionDrum or pinionEscapementWheel) and pass the argument twist_factor.
It adds herringbone to the gears by exactly twist_factor times the size of the teeth of the pinion, e.g. twist_factor=1 means the pinion has 45 degree herringbone.
The default value if you don't pass the argument is zero, which corresponds to normal gears.

description.text:
Watch made from 1921 pocket watch Hamilton movement and my 3D Printer.   
The Trench watch was a type of watch that came into use by the military during World War I, as pocket watches were not practical in combat. It was a transitional design between pocket watches and wrist watches, incorporating features of both.

40mm watch glass from eBay x2, for front and back
40mm (also known as 12s) pocket watch movement eBay, 17j is a quality movement and I paid $45 for a working movement. Printed in PLA 20% infill
2 shells
.2mm layer height
standard PLA setting Simplify 3D: Each Watch should include:
1x watch body
1x watch face ring
1x spacer for use with watch crystal, print as many as needed for use without crystal
2x watch link end 22mm
1x clasp
10x watch link 22mm, or as many as needed To Snap together/apart the links, get two of the links at a 90 degree angle to each-other. You'll notice that the rectangular male 'peg' will match the female side with the notch. Update:
Watch body and watch link end now have the same locking tab as the rest of the watch band.

description.text:
V1.2 is out http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:846403
= An OpenSCAD model of a direct drive extruder, suitable for 1.75mm and 3mm filament. Fully customizable. If you make this thing, be proud and show your work. Upload a photo with "I made One". Please read the instructions.

  • The provides .stl file is useless if you use other vitamins as I use. Check the .scad file for comparison.

Caution
=
If you want to use the provides .stl file, you HAVE TO use the same vitamins as I did. You can alternate them and edit the according parameters online with customizer or OpenScad on your computer.
Most parameters depend on each other and choosing a wrong vitamin will result in an unusable extruder because parts won't fit. Check the parameters in the .scad file and compare them with your vitamins. Bill of materials (aka vitamins)
=
3x 24mm m3 screws (accurate), for mounting of the stepper motor
2x 26mm m3 screws, for clamping the hotend
2x 30mm m3 screws, for tightening the lever
4x m3 nuts
4x m3 washers, for tightening the lever
2x springs, for tightening the lever
1x 625 ball bearing
1x 16mm m5 screw, cut of the head and dremel a slot in one end, for mounting the ball bearing
1x bowden tube, from the hotend to the hobbed gear
1x bowden coupling, to connect your filament spool
1x hobbed gear, 5mm id
1x NEMA 17 high torque stepper motor
1x jHead mount compatible hotend, i.e. E3D V6

author: Professional3D

description.text: The starting point for making a filament guide for the RL200 extruder.

I only uploaded this because I was badgered into it. Really it's so simple, people should be designing and printing it for themselves as it's the only way they'll learn, and I find designing almost as satisfying as printing parts.
Download Autodesk 123D Design, it's FREE! - RANT OVER. Use 100% fill because you are going to be machining this and do not want any infill. After printing the basic piece you will need to cut a 6mm thread on the outside and drill a 2mm hole up the centre using the printed hole as your guide. Screw 1 piece into the extruder arm under the brass fitment (from the top) and then screw the other piece into the exit hole in the extruder block under the knurled wheel. Both pieces should end as close to the wheels as possible but not impeding them. I also dished the top using a countersink to help guide the filament down to the hole.

A simple parametric door handle. I designed it because mine was broken.

title: XRD-sample holder STOE STADI P COMBI

description.text: The XRD sample holder is designed for the STADI P COMBI developed by STOE.  It is a powder diffractometer for high-throughput and combinatorial measurements in transmission geometry.  The STADI P COMBI offers highest efficiency combined with all the advantages of the STADI P system.

The XRD sample holder has been designed on AutoCAD and printed with the Stratasys Dimension 1200 es 3D printer. One of the requirements at which has to met, is the fact that the X-ray beam may not cause a reaction with the polymer substance out of
which the plate is made. This restriction has two goals: first, avoiding the plate holder to fall apart, second, avoiding wrong interpretations when measuring a sample. The material should be as hard as possible to avoid abrasion after using it on a longterm basis. In order to meet these two requirements, the sample holder has been printed using ABS. This material is indeed very rigid and is also amorphous, so that it does not interfere with the X-ray beam.

author: Jayuk

description.text:
A fully automatic pump, with which the desired fluid amount can be pumped with. The first design sketches were inspired by open-source designs available on the Internet (Wijnen, Hunt, Anzalone, & Pearce, 2014), but didn’t match our quality requirements or functionality requirements. None of the available open-source designs were offering the possibility to go back and forth with the syringe plunger. Most of the designs were experimental, didn’t have a convenient structure and allowed the user to use only one type and size of syringe. This is why it’s been decided to completely re-imagine the pump design with inspiration coming directly from the commercially available syringe pumps. The resulting design is an easy to use device with convenient features that allow the
user to use multiple syringe sizes, an easy-to-use system for the
replacement of the syringe, and a bi-directional pumping
possibility. Each one of the five parts of the pump has been sketched on paper first, and the dimensions have been calculated according to standard sizes of commercially available screws, nuts, metallic tubes, ball bearings and couplers.

The design based on the sketches has been 3D modelled using the CAD software AutoCAD (source, company). Five different designs have been created, corresponding to the five different parts of the pump. The first piece is the base plate that includes the syringe support on one side and the motor support on the other side. Each of those supports contains excavations to leave room for the different screws, guiding bars, ball bearing and z-coupler. The “plunger holder” is made out of two parts. The first one is the one attached to the guiding screw, powered by the motor. It is the one that will be pushing the syringe plunger to deliver its content. Two slots in the block allow two nuts to go down to the screw axis, and will allow that part to move forwards and backwards. The second one has two functions: holding the plunger straight and pull the plunger when the first part goes backwards. The last two parts are the “syringe holders”. Those are made to firmly hold the syringe on the syringe support in the front part of the base plate, and have been designed in two different sizes in order to adapt to every existing syringe sizes. After a first test of the syringe pump, a design improvement has
been made to the second part of the plunger holder, in order for it to be stronger, and to avoid having screws preventing the plunger to run its course entirely.

author: BPace07

title: Stone wall (3") with arched opening (1.5") plus doors for RPGs

description.text:
The piece is made to print 3" wide, with an arched opening that is 1.5" wide. Four door files are included as well ... a solid single door, a double door, a door with a barred window (such as for a cell), and a full cage door.  
The wall piece is quite large, as it has a rocky texture on the bricks and archway that add a lot of polygons.  
This piece is useful for dungeons made with the Open Forge files, Dwarven Forge, Hirst Arts, Dungeonstone, etc., where the pieces are 2" wide on the outside, and corridors are often 3" wide on the inside. This piece allows a gamer to quickly add a doorway in a hallway, or just before a room, etc. There is no base - the piece is intended to sit on top of the other dungeon pieces.  
I will also be putting out a 3" wide piece that will have a 1" wide doorway soon (along with matching doors).
Pieces are made in 3DS Max by scratch. The STL files cleaned up in netfabb.

description.text: This is a case for a tiny SainSmart 1.3" OLED screen (http://www.amazon.co.uk/SainSmart-Serial-128X64-Module-Arduino/dp/B00MQL08R6). To use this you'll need the display, and arduino, a computer to run the control software on and a running OctoPrint server controlling your printer. The screen is connected to an Arduino, running this software: https://github.com/kirberich/octoprint-monitor. The software connects to an OctoPrint server to fetch information about the printer and the current print job. The arduino needs to be connected to a computer that takes care of the communication with OctoPrint. The display shows the general printer status, progress of an ongoing job and a minimal status during the night, including a warning if the printer is still hot.

title: FatShark Radio + 3DR 900mhz Mount for 2014 Quad Frame

description.text:
Ultimately I plan on building a 100% custom top deck for this quad but thought I would post the first part of the project.  This part is a nice container for a FatShark FPV radio + the 3dr telem radio.  Both parts sit cleanly and can be tightened in with a single zip-tie.  
Be careful pulling the ziptie, the output walls are a bit too thin and mine cracked(still in service) but a warning to others none-the-less.
Printing mine PLA, 15% 20% infill @ .3mm resolution.  Nothing fancy for these prototypes!

comments.text: Yours will look nicer because I adjusted the support height on the 3DR radio compartment so you won't need the "spacer foam and paper" visible in my picture.  I'm using an older prototype for now.

title: Scalextric dunlop bridge riser 4 lane extender

description.text: This piece was made to raise up the Scalextric pedestrian bridge to fit over a 4 lane slot car track. There are two files, the first is for a color print if you have dual color printer. The taller file is for more clearance. I would recommend printing in yellow and then coming back with a black or gray primer for the stone work with a light dry brushing on the final parts.. I printed them both a .3 resolution with a 10% infill and it took about 2.25 hours to complete 1 side. I used http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:30584 for the base, and then made the stairs and sliced off the back to allow the cars to pass.

printed fine at .3 with 10% infill. 5mm Brim used to keep it from peeling.  
scalextric_dunlop_bridge_riser_4_lane_extender.stl is for a track that is level with the ground that the piece will sit on. for example a routed wood track.  
tall_dunlop_bridge_extesion.stl is for tracks tha tsit a few mm higher, for example if you are not using any borders to sit the bridge on.  
2_small_brick_scalextric_dunlop_bridge_riser is a tall bridge but made with small detailed bricks.

comments.text:
I have printed this 3 times (1st was too small) and I needed to scale this up 30% to fit a gray scalextric Dunlop Bridge.
Could use some hand rails on the steps :) otherwise a nice design!

author: Tioh

title: Bracket for Chineese HotEnd with autolevel and fan

description.text:
My latest design to improve the printing quality of my beloved Prusa i3.
Older bracket was designed to hold another type of hotend and cannot bear the new HotEnds i bought sometime ago for my other Delta Rostock.
So I was in need of another bracket and a new type of leveling for my aluminium buildplate. And here comes the P3DBracket for Chineese E3D like hotends.
To make it clear:
IT WILL NOT FIT A REAL E3D HOTEND
Chineese type are quite different in dimensions and are not ALLMETAL. You HAVE BEEN WARNED. You can print in ABS or PLA. Mine's are PLA and have 150 hours of printing with NO DEFORMATION AT ALL of the bracket. I've included an inductive sensor version and a 9g servo version with his arm.

Large 7 or 14 segment LED display, with optional colons and dots. Default STL files are 150mm (~6") tall, with a 10 degree slant. You might want to rotate them 100 degrees after import (90 degrees + your chosen slant value) to best align on a Makerbot / Clone style bed. Defaults are sized height wise to fit into a 1" deep art frame, such as these: http://www.dickblick.com/products/blick-metal-gallery-frames/

These print 'upside down'.  Once done printing, flip them over and screw them to the mounting surface.
They are mostly hollow, so infill and other settings don't really matter.

description.text: This smple tablet stand was made for cheap Wexler Tab-400 tablet using as clock/calendar

Well, better than my previous rudder (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:806945). Rotating the worm gear both adjusts the rudder angle and also tilts the rudder fore and aft. For normal steering angles (+/-20 degrees) the tilting does not affect the steering. If you crank rudder all the way over to 120 degrees, though, you can lift the rudder clean out of the water. The whole assembly straps to the back deck of the kayak (in this case, my Advanced Elements Convertible) and breaks down easily for transport. See how it works here: https://youtu.be/B3C8raQL2_4

Instructions:
You will need to print the following parts (all 0.2mm layer, 4 perimeter, 25% infill):
1 gear.stl
1 worm.stl
1 wormbracket.stl
1 bigpulley.stl
1 yoke.stl
1 bladepulley.stl
3 idler.stl
2 t-clamp.stl
3 tiedown.stl
2 u-joint.stl
1 spider.stl
1 handle.stl The yoke is the largest part and needs a 5" x 8" bed. All others can be printed on a 6" x 6" bed. You will also need:
16 8-32 x 1" screws
4 8-32 x 3/4" screws
7 8-32 x 3/8" screws
13 8-32 nuts
3 1/4-20 x 1" hex bolt
2 1/4-20 nuts
2 1/4" standard washers
2 1/4" fender washers
4 6-32 set screws
2 3/16" dia x 0.55" stainless steel rod
1 3/16" dia x 0.75" stainless steel rod
1 5/16" dia x 4.75" stainless steel rod
1 36" long x 0.75 dia aluminum tube
1 24" long x 0.75 dia aluminum tube
2 12" long x 0.75 dia aluminum tube
1 rudder blade (as per blade.pdf)
heavy duty nylon string for pulley system
nylon cord for lashing All fasteners should be stainless steel.
  • Insert screws and nuts into all parts with tube clamps and tighten only lightly.
  • Tap the holes in the gear, spider, bigpulley and bladepulley with an 8-32 tap. Tap the setscrew holes in the worm and yoke with a 6-32 tap.
  • Insert the 12" tube (worm-tube) thru the wormbracket, inserting the worm as you push the tube thru. Secure the worm with one set screw. Use the other set screw hole as a guide to drill a 0.109" hole (7/64th) in the aluminum tube. Insert the second set screw so that it penetrates the tube. Repeat with the first set screw hole.
  • Press the 2 shorter 3/16" dia pins into the holes on the inside of the yoke. Press the longer 3/16" pin into the bottom flange of the yoke. If the pins don't press in securely, glue them in with superglue. Put the 2 idler pulleys over the 2 short pins.
  • Assemble the bigpulley and gear into the yoke and then insert the 5/16" rod as an axle. Secure the rod with the 2 setscrews in the yoke.
  • Mount the yoke bracket on the bigpulley with the 1/4-20 bolts and standard washers. Adjust the position so that the gears engage fully, but without too much friction. Now tighten the clamp on the worm bracket so that there is a small amount of friction when turning the worm. This will prevent the rudder from back-driving the worm.
  • Take a 36" long piece of nylon string and secure the center of it in the notch in the blade pulley using a shorter 8-32 screw. (Make sure the screw does not stick out the other side of the pulley.) Then screw the blade to the side of the pulley. Secure the blade/bladepulley to the yoke with a 1/4-20 bolt and 2 fender washers. Use two nuts locked together to secure the bolt.
  • Insert the 24" tube into the big pulley and tighten in place. Assemble tie-down pieces onto the 24" tube and onto one end of the other 12" tube (the cross-tube). Assemble the cross-tube to the 24" tube with the t-clamp. Lash the rudder assembly to the rear deck of your kayak. Make sure to lash the end of the cross tube down to the kayak deck as this is what keeps the entire assembly from rotating. You'll have to play around with the exact positioning for your kayak. You may also need to adjust the tube lengths.
  • Now finish the string & pulley assembly: put the 3rd idler pulley over the pin in the flange on the yoke. Take one end of the string and run it over the blade pulley, under this idler pulley, up through the hole, around the left upper idler, around the big bully and then secure loosely with a screw in the bladepulley, up through the hole, over the right upper idler and around the other side of the bigpulley. Adjust the worm so that the rudder is pointing straight ahead and is also vertical. Pull both sides of the string taught and tighten with the clamping screw. This will take a bit of fussing and you'll want to study the video.
  • Assemble the u-joint between the worm tube and the 36" tube and mount the handle on the other end of the 36" tube. Make sure the handle end of the tube is loosely supported by a strap on the side of the kayak or else you will end up breaking the wormbracket.
  • The easiest way to disassemble for transport is to just remove the bigpulley from the 24" tube, and remove the u-joint from the worm tube.

description.text: This is a stand for the Art Asylum/Diamond Select Toys Star Trek The Original Series phaser. It is designed to display the phaser attractively with the body of the phaser being roughly parallel to the surface it is sitting on.

I suggest printing in .2 resolution with at least 50% infill. The stand works more by balance than weight, however.  
The phaser should slide in slightly loose. If your phaser fits too tightly you make scratch the paint if you try to force it in. (In that case, upsize by 1%-2% and try printing it again.)
